contentrichtext.text: In [[abstract algebra]], an [[algebraic extension|algebraic field extension]] ''L''/''K'' is said to be '''normal''' if ''L'' is the [[splitting field]] of a family of [[polynomial]]s in ''K''[''X'']. [[Nicolas Bourbaki|Bourbaki]] calls such an extension a '''quasi-[[Galois extension]]'''. == Equivalent properties and examples == The normality of ''L''/''K'' is equivalent to either of the following properties. Let ''K''<sup>''a''</sup> be an [[algebraic closure]] of ''K'' containing ''L''. * Every [[embedding]] σ of ''L'' in ''K''<sup>''a''</sup> that restricts to the identity on ''K'', satisfies σ(''L'') = ''L''. In other words, σ is an [[automorphism]] of ''L'' over ''K''. * Every [[irreducible polynomial]] in ''K''[''X''] that has one root in ''L'', has all of its roots in ''L'', that is, it decomposes into linear factors in ''L''[''X'']. (One says that the polynomial ''splits'' in ''L''.) If ''L'' is a finite extension of ''K'' that is [[separable extension|separable]] (for example, this is automatically satisfied if ''K'' is finite or has characteristic zero) then the following property is also equivalent: * There exists an irreducible polynomial whose roots, together with the elements of ''K'', generate ''L''. (One says that ''L'' is the [[splitting field]] for the polynomial.) For example, <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2})</math> is a normal extension of <math>\mathbb{Q}</math>, since it is a splitting field of ''x''<sup>2</sup> − 2. On the other hand, <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})</math> is not a normal extension of <math>\mathbb{Q}</math> since the irreducible polynomial ''x''<sup>3</sup> − 2 has one root in it (namely, <math>\sqrt[3]{2}</math>), but not all of them (it does not have the non-real cubic roots of 2). The fact that <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})</math> is not a normal extension of <math>\mathbb{Q}</math> can also be seen using the first of the three properties above. The field <math>\mathbb{A}</math> of [[algebraic number]]s is an algebraic closure of <math>\mathbb{Q}</math> containing <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})</math>. On the other hand :<math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})=\{a+b\sqrt[3]{2}+c\sqrt[3]{4}\in\mathbb{A}\,|\,a,b,c\in\mathbb{Q}\}</math> and, if ω is one of the two non-real cubic roots of 2, then the map :<math>\begin{array}{rccc}\sigma:&\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})&\longrightarrow&\mathbb{A}\\&a+b\sqrt[3]{2}+c\sqrt[3]{4}&\mapsto&a+b\omega+c\omega^2\end{array}</math> is an embedding of <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})</math> in <math>\mathbb{A}</math> whose restriction to <math>\mathbb{Q}</math> is the identity. However, σ is not an automorphism of <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})</math>. For any prime ''p'', the extension <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[p]{2}, \zeta_p)</math> is normal of degree ''p''(''p'' − 1). It is a splitting field of ''x<sup>p</sup>'' − 2. Here <math>\zeta_p</math> denotes any ''p''th [[primitive root of unity]]. The field <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2}, \zeta_3)</math> is the normal closure (see below) of <math>\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})</math>. == Other properties == Let ''L'' be an extension of a field ''K''. Then: * If ''L'' is a normal extension of ''K'' and if ''E'' is an intermediate extension (i.e., ''L'' ⊃ ''E'' ⊃ ''K''), then ''L'' is a normal extension of ''E''. * If ''E'' and ''F'' are normal extensions of ''K'' contained in ''L'', then the [[compositum]] ''EF'' and ''E'' ∩ ''F'' are also normal extensions of ''K''. ==Normal closure== If ''K'' is a field and ''L'' is an algebraic extension of ''K'', then there is some algebraic extension ''M'' of ''L'' such that ''M'' is a normal extension of ''K''. Furthermore, [[up to isomorphism]] there is only one such extension which is minimal, i.e. such that the only subfield of ''M'' which contains ''L'' and which is a normal extension of ''K'' is ''M'' itself. This extension is called the '''normal closure''' of the extension ''L'' of ''K''. If ''L'' is a finite extension of ''K'', then its normal closure is also a finite extension. == See also == *[[Galois extension]] *[[Normal basis]] == References == * {{Lang Algebra}} * {{citation | last = Jacobson | first = Nathan | author-link = Nathan Jacobson | title = Basic Algebra II| edition = 2nd | year = 1989 | publisher = W. H.
